awd_titl_txt: GEM:  Exploring the Relative Influence of Different Classes of Ion Outflow on the Coupled Dynamics of the Magnetosphere-Ionosphere-Thermosphere System
awd_abstract_narration:
The Geospace Environment Modeling (GEM) program addresses the most critical problems in magnetospheric physics. It is focused research where the topics are selected by the scientific community based on their importance and timeliness. 
An understanding of dynamics of the magnetosphere requires a quantitative understanding of the sources of the plasma. There are two main sources of plasma for the magnetosphere: the solar wind and the ionosphere. In order to understand the solar wind, magnetosphere and ionosphere system it is important that both sources of plasma be included in models of the overall all system. Most emphasis over the years has been on the solar wind source. This proposal will quantify the outflow from the ionosphere. The approach in this study will be to use the Coupled Magnetosphere Ionosphere Thermosphere (CMIT) simulation system including a new, flexible polar wind outflow module (IPW). The resulting simulation code will be made available to the entire space physics community through the Community Coordinated Modeling Center (CCMC).
This study will address two questions: 1) which classes of ion outflow have the most significant effects on the coupled magnetosphere-ionosphere-thermosphere (MIT) system and 2) to what extent do the effects of ion outflow on the coupled MIT dynamics depend on the mechanism producing the outflow?  Three versions of the polar wind module will be developed: 1) a classical polar wind model, 2) a configuration where the upper boundary conditions on the polar wind are set by the magnetospheric model, thereby allowing centrifugal forces and pressure gradients to provide the outflow, and 3) a configuration which includes a heuristic model of transversely accelerated ions regulated by inputs like the Alfvenic Poynting flux. The three types of outflow will be evaluated by calculating their influences on the polar cap potential, Dst, hemispheric outflow rates and hemispheric power, and qualitative changes in the magnetospheric convection.

por.por_cntn:
This project, completed by SRI International, supported the development of a new space weather modeling capability. Space weather can heat ions in the high-latitude ionosphere, the ionized portion of the upper atmosphere, and cause them to escape into the magnetosphere, the cavity in the solar wind carved out by the Earth's magnetic field. The introduction of these extra ions into the magnetosphere can change the magnetospheric dynamics, and thus change space weather. This project developed new modeling tools that can capture the feedback loops created by ion outflow and used these new tools to explore the consequences of the feedback loops.

This project coupled the recently developed ionosphere/polar wind model (IPWM), a model of the high latitude ionosphere and ion outflow, to the multi-fluid Lyon Fedder Mobarry (MFLFM) magnetospheric magnetohydrodynamics model, which is a widely used global magnetospheric model. The model coupling included various experimental  parameterizations of the relationship between magnetospheric energy inputs and ion energization. The most significant finding is that the coupled dynamics are highly sensitive to the way the magnetosphere regulates ion energization. The kinds of magnetospheric dynamics that emerge from the coupled simulations depend on how much ion outflow is produced as well as the spatial and temporal distribution of that outflow. Some, but not all, of the coupled simulations spontaneously produced magnetospheric sawtooth oscillations, a quasi-periodic phenomenon involving the build up and release of energy from the magnetotail every 2-4 hours. The attached images illustrate the evolution of magnetospheric ion density (top), ionospheric outflow fluxes (second row), polar cap open magnetic flux (third row), and magnetic reconnection rates (bottom) during a simulated magnetospheric sawtooth event from one of the simulations.

This project was the first NSF award for the Principal Investigator, an early career scientist. The coupled modeling tools developed during this project are being made available to the broader community to support a variety of other investigations. The PI wrote a comprehensive user manual for the coupled model and distributed the source code and user manual to several other researchers. Results from ongoing development have been shared with the community through regular presentations at the Geospace Environment Modeling Workshop, the American Geophysical Union Meeting, and peer-reviewed publications.
